text: Fwiw, I always thought law/DOJ-guidance should be: A POTUS may be indicted while in office but not tried. Otherwise, statute of lims could expire, making POTUS un-prosecutable. Makes no sense to me that a POTUS should get that advantage - nothing in Const calls for it.

text: It’s too complicated a debate to have on Twitter, but comes down to which imperfect process would be prone to least likelihood of abuse. I think exec pushes envelope more knowing can say ‘but judge approved it.’ But you’re right that we have FISA for a reason.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I have given judges what turned out to be inaccurate information, and have had to confess error. Not proud moments but culture of SDNY was our standing with court required fessing up when we got something wrong. It happens.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Should add, fwiw, I do not like FISA, & have always thought judges should not be involved in foreign intel collection. Exec w/ cong’l oversight would be more accountable, and it’s not a judicial process so harms judiciary to be seen as rubber stamp.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: The argument should be that DOJ & FISA judges have higher duty to follow rules and scrutinize applications because, unlike criminal proceeding where there’s eventual discovery and hearings, that’s all the due process warrant target will ever get.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: In nearly 20 yrs as a prosecutor, and hundreds of warrants, I never had a hearing to get a warrant. I had judges tell me ‘no,’ or tell me I needed to beef up this or that allegation with more solid evidence. But never a hearing.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Folks, there generally are no hearings on warrants, and you don’t want there to be because the four corners of the warrant application must state the probable cause. If they don’t, the judge should reject the application, not hold a hearing.

text: Even if subject of investigation relatively unimportant, I would say there should be real evidence of crime before a prosecutor is assigned. For POTUS, governance of country is more important than need for investigative secrecy, so I think we are entitled to know probe’s basis.

text: Orin, the bit about the president ‘brazenly lying’ is where you lose me. Even if it’s true, he is lying about someone else’s behavior for reasons that are easily understandable - that’s not excusable in a POTUS, but it’s not criminally culpable.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: My view, which is doubtless informed by doing nat-sec cases, is that sometimes there are considerations more important to the country than investigative secrecy - which in most situations is, I agree, paramount.

text: Trump's kowtowing to Putin on election meddling was shameful. But the whole idea of meeting with Putin was wrong. He is a thug, an aggressor who annexes other countries' territory and assassinates people in Western cities. We do not need better relations with thugs.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Leaving aside his 2016 election shenanigans, it ratifies his annexation of Crimea, for one thing. Why should we be meeting with a dictator who seizes other countries’ territory? The meeting says we’re fine with that. Putin should be shunned - regarded as the lowlife he is.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: No, I don’t.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Mr. President, it’s not about how well *you* do. It’s about whether America does well by having a meeting you don’t have to have that inflates the prestige of an anti-American thug regime we should be squeezing rather than burnishing.

text: I always think of this when I talk about people in good prosecutor’s office checking their politics at the door. If you assumed people infected legal judgment with politics, you’d have guessed wrong on where many stood. Everyone tried to get it right.

text: My recollection is thinking there could be no case on POTUS, but some thought could be honest services fraud consp on others if could prove pardon-for-votes quid pro quo. I didn’t think you could get around const’l issue - except by impeachment.

text: In fact, as chief AUSA, I had the part of the Clinton pardons investigation involving NewSquare and urged the office to shut it down on constitutional grounds. Finally shut down later, more on lack of quid pro quo evidence than on my theory. I still think I was right.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: You are right that that's the quote, and that he should have thought to clarify whether he was paraphrasing Comey or giving Trump's version. Doesn't mean we can't infer from context that he was doing the former - he was correcting Stephanopoulos' portrayal of Comey's version.

author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: You probably saw it, which is always better than transcript (esp rushed one) that I'm going on. Not sure I'd take your advice, tho. I think Comey's version is more credible and it's a dumb thing for POTUS to deny, so I'd be arguing that even by Jim's version, no obstruction.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I think throughout the interview Rudy hedges in a lot of places about what he knows from POTUS versus what he knows from the public record and other conversations. I doubt anything he said would be admissible in court as an admission by Trump through an agent - not clear enough.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Josh, I don't think so. Appears he was correcting Stephanopoulos, who wrongly said Comey's version was that he had been 'directed'; Giuliani was saying that Comey's own version was a request - 'Can you give a man a break' - not necessarily that Trump now adopts that version.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Brad, they flip from courtroom legal defense to impeachment w/o clarifying. Personally, I don’t think a POTUS could be indicted for legal act (eg pardon) due to alleged corrupt intent. I have no doubt a POTUS could be impeached for it, tho, if Congress found abuse of power.

text: Julie, we still don’t know what Contreras conflict was, and Strzok may have been good for Flynn. More importantly, Flynn may well not want plea vacated because it may still be better for him than broader Mueller indictment - that’s why he pled in first place, I think.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Flynn’s got a lot in his favor in terms of mitigation and should get no time. If Mueller wants delay, I don’t see what’s in it for Kelner to fight him. He wants Mueller to say Flynn was very cooperative. I doubt there’s anything more to it.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Good points. I think people who speculate Flynn might seek to w/draw plea don’t factor in 1) very uphill legally, 2) as much personal as legal decision (wants it over), 3) in unlikely event he prevailed, case doesn’t end — Mueller could indict him on whatever.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Yup. Likely one of those cases where lawyers content to roll it over forever (no upside for defense counsel to fight prosecutor who wants sentencing delay), and judge wants to make sure defendant really ok with another adjournment.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Ari, I think ‘fume’ overstates it. If Flynn cooperating & expected to testify, sentencing should be ppd indefinitely. If he’s not, should’ve happened already. Judge prob’ly irked that it’s in limbo & wants Flynn there to make sure he consents to Mueller delay. More on this tom’w.

text: I'm afraid I don't. I'm also influenced by the ripe dead certainty that if Bush had run an informant at 3 peeps (incl co-chair) of 2008 Obama campaign, anyone who tried to parse whether it was really spying would be ostracized from polite company.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: No, it’s not necessary. It would have been prudent since we don’t want incumbent admin snooping on opp party campaign unless there’s a really good reason. I think debate is over: What’s a really good reason?
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I had the Lightning, so there’s that. I prob’ly go with Vegas on theory that Ovechkin is an agent of a foreign power ...
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: No, they can’t be unwitting. Page is a US citizen; if he didn’t act *knowingly* he can’t be agent of foreign power under FISA, 50 USC 1801(b)(2) - https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/50/1801 ….
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Susan, I sat thru zillion trials where prosecutors called the operatives ‘undercovers’ & ‘informants,’ while defense lawyers called them ‘spies’ & ‘rats.’ Commonsense people got the point. So no, I’m not even a little concerned. I want to know why done, I don’t care what called.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Also, you may be offended by the term ‘spy’; I am not. Put aside that it’s commonly used interchangeably with ‘informant’; If the FBI had solid evidence that Page was a clandestine agent of a foreign power, I would enthusiastically support treating him as a spy.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Steve, they had to argue probable cause that he was knowingly engaged in clandestine activities on behalf of a government (Russia) against another country (ours). Otherwise they don’t get any of the 4 warrants. If you don’t think that’s labeling him a spy, we’ll have to disagree.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Column’s about silly claim Obama admin didn’t *spy* on Trump campaign (Issue is: Did they have sufficient reason, not did they do it?). Question: By whom is there more known, verified spying evidence: Halper or Carter Page (whom Obama DOJ-FBI labeled a spy 4x in FISA Court)?
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Jason, no, but the Aug 2 memo does not make it conditional on ‘arising out of’ Russia investigation. It expressly gives SC jurisdiction on Manafort/Ukraine. I don’t like it b/c I think SC bad institution, but judge has no business telling DOJ what prosecutor to assign case to.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: True, but it’s up to POTUS to give a clear, accountable order. Railing on Twitter or grousing thru lawyers is a cop out. If he is ORDERING that this information be disclosed, then ORDER it.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Wish there were vehicle to challenge SC’s jurisdiction. What happened here (prosecutor given unfettered jurisdiction to find crime) should not happen. But DOJ clearly had auth to assign Manafort case to SC. Whether SC jurisdiction otherwise problematic irrelevant to Manafort case
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Sean, I don’t think so. I am obviously a critic of how this was done, but I believe that if it’s clear that SC has jurisdiction to do Manafort case(and Aug2 memo makes that clear), the theoretical outer limit of SC’s jurisdiction is not this judge’s concern.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: 4/ I respect and like you, so I apologize for losing my temper.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: 3/ I have said that if SC can show proof of a crime that POTUS is complicit in and that SC needs evidence only POTUS can provide, he should be able to question POTUS.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: 2/ my point is that it makes no sense to say we need to grill POTUS, but it’s not important to grab all potentially relevant evidence of agent misconduct.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Tom, 1/ we apparently disagree about the relevance of Strzok. I don’t think I did this, but you’re a smart guy so if you think I did, I’ll clarify: I am not saying Strzok has anything to do with whether Trump colluded/obstructed.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Sheesh. It’s not that they’re connected substantively. It’s that you should take a consistent position about demanding production of evidence. You don’t get that?
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Tom, maybe if you pretend Trump’s not president your considerable brain will kick in again. Job of POTUS singularly important. If you think he should be subpoenaed, you can’t say it’s too intrusive to subpoena agents involved in misconduct to determine scope of misconduct.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Even if this weren’t incoherent, I’d have no idea what you’re talking about. I don’t think POTUS obstructed justice or colluded with Russia, but that has nothing to do with Strzok. He’s relevant on gov’t conduct, which is important even if you’d rather not deal.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Where have I said that about Strzok’s texts? Main thing I’ve said about Strzok is people should reserve judgment b/c I’m told he’s a good agent and he did not accuse Flynn of lying. Of course his texts are relevant to whether there was misconduct. But you’re just making shit up.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: You’re so Trump deranged you’re lost. I’ve catalogued Trump lies repeatedly. But he’s still president. He’s not Trump, he’s president. That’s not equivalence. You can’t say it’s essential to grill POTUS, but we don’t need to subpoena other potentially relevant evidence.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Fine. Genius was saying that I’m saying that, and I haven’t come close to saying that.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Tom, no one is saying investigation of chief executive should be dumped. The point is that if you’re going to demand POTUS interview, then you shouldn’t decide other avenues are foreclosed. You’re too smart not to get that, so I’m thinking you’re a waste of time.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: #SchiffMemo highlights Russian effort to recruit Page, as @ByronYork notes in his piece, but effort to recruit an American is not enough for a FISA warrant. My @NRO column:
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: To be clear, I mean I've written a lot of *criminal* warrants (same 'alternative investigative techniques' rule in T-III). I helped agents write some FISA warrants in mid-90s (pre-Wall), but DOJ-NatSecDiv that deals w/ FISA Court (OIPR back in those days) runs show on that.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: It's a very fair point. Not sure I've been consistent about including this in every column, but we clearly don't know everything FBI knows and must draw inferences based on what's been disclosed + common sense. You are right, clearly, that this is not as good as knowing for sure.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: They’ve been amazingly open about fact C-I inv is about Trump-Russia. Once surveillance is up and running, go back to stored communications. Steele dossier allegations they included show Trump-Russia was focus. Inconceivable they would not have looked for comms w/ Trump campaign.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I’m saying there is reason to suspect this rule has been violated and, as I observed in column, it would be good to know what DOJ said in warrant. (I’ve written many warrants; this is not always easy standard to satisfy outside org crime context.)
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Inference from 3 memos, incl Grassley-Graham, which says Steele dossier main basis. Plus, no charge against Page tho FBI dealing w/ him since 2013. I am presuming him innocent in absence of evidence to contrary + strong motive to produce if exists.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Orin, I'm drawing an inference from facts that (a) it has not leaked (cf. Page, Manafort), (b) govt officials say no warrant on person while officially in campaign (GP was, CP & PM out by Sept), (c) no allegation GP an agent of foreign power (he heard things).

text: Yes. I was worried about Russia when Obama admin "resetting,"  &  Trump's reprehensible bouquets to Putin was a big reason I opposed him in GOP primaries. Admins of both parties for 20 yrs have deluded themselves about Russia as "strategic partner" -- they're our adversary.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: DOJ used to believe distinction b/w crim & C-I was critically important – fear of using former as pretext for latter was why “wall” imposed in 90s. That was overreaction, but doesn’t mean distinction unimportant. /8x
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: No prob if conduct counterintel, happen to find crime from which DOJ conflicted, then appoint SC. But that’s not what happened. /7
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: There is no a basis in regs to appoint special counsel to conduct counterintel inv – which makes sense b/c only need SC for prosecution, which is not objective of counterintel. /6
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: There were not grounds to believe Trump campaign conspired in a crime at time Mueller appointed. /5
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: But special counsel appointed only if grounds for crim investigation from which DOJ conflicted. /4
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I continue, for example, to be baffled by gov’t failure to seize DNC servers & to farm out forensic analysis to Dem contractor, which would harm prosecution. /3
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: There is no doubt that DOJ had auth to investigate Russian interference in election, without limitations (except those that always apply), and should do so. /2
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: A special counsel is triggered by 2 things – not just a crime but a conflict. /1
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Carissa, interference happened notwithstanding sanctions already imposed due to prior Russian aggression. I'm all for sanctions, but insufficient on their own. Untriable indictment no help. Last round of sanctions was theatrical support for political collusion narrative.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: A response to very weak response by @RepJerryNadler to #NunesMemo & thoughts on 'vicarious credibility' theory of apologists for #SteeleDossier use - my @NRO SuperBowl column:
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: FISA, at 50 USCode Sec 1804(a)(6)(C): in application, gov’t must certify “that such information cannot reasonably be obtained by normal investigative techniques.”
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: 3/ Usual rule w/ electronic surveillance is must satisfy court that alternative investigative techniques have been tried and failed or would fail if tried. Was he such a central player in big plot that talking to him would have tipped everyone off & undermined investigation?
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: 2/ What I'd like to know is: Since he cooperated w/ FBI/DOJ in prior Russia case (see pp. 12-13 in complaint, link below), why did they feel that needed FISA surveillance on him? Why not go talk to him & take his temperature re Steele allegations? http://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/2015_0126_spyring2.pdf …
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Julie, 1/ @ChuckRossDC reported a while back that he'd met agents 4x for combined 10hrs. That's before Mueller appointed, but it's with same investigation Mueller is running. Between that and congressional testimony, seems he's provided lots of info.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: But we already know it included more than Steele — issue is how necessary Steele was to probable cause showing. If essential, the omissions are bad, regardless of how many judges involved.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Yup. Let’s see the transcript. Dems & FBI/DOJ had opp’ty to review memo before release. If they now say something’s wrong, don’t tell me your recollection, show me the documents.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: If the claim is that material info about source credibility was omitted, what’s the relevance of fact that 4 GOP-appointed FISA judges approved warrants? Question is whether any 1 of them would have ok’d with full disclosure.  We don’t know answer to that.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I hope so. We really haven’t had great NYC college hoops since BigEast glory days when Johnnies were relevant.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Tough season for good guy Chris Mullin.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: You’re assuming focus of investigation remained Trump throughout. May not be so. Recall, Trump told during this time he’s not a suspect. We don’t know what surveillance yielded and what direction investigation took. Focus should be Russia, not Trump.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: 2 diff investigations. In first, he’s target of Russian intel recruitment and cooperates w/ US govt against Russia. In second, he’s seen by US govt as agent of Russia working against US.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Advocates for addressing FISA abuse are self-defeating if argument is seen as Trojan horse to attack Mueller inv. Mueller champions self-defeat by portraying his inv as synonymous with ’Trump colluded with Russia.’
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Yes, see @EliLake on this point. https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-02-02/the-memo-is-neither-treasonous-nor-worse-than-watergate …
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I don’t understand commentary about whether FISA warrant is ‘invalid.’ That’s crim law concept. FISA is intel — it’s not like govt has to give back information it learns. This is not prosecution situation where not fruit-of-poisonous-tree doctrine applies.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: My working theory: neither side wants full disclosure. For Dems, it would show reliance on dossier. For Reps, govt theory was Putin could have blackmail material on Trump. Flattering to neither, so we’ll not get disclosure and keep arguing over snippets and shadows.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Typically excellent from Eli.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: My recollection - not sure I buy this, but fwiw - is reporting says FBI/DOJ had eye on Page from July but delayed seeking FISA warrant until Trump campaign & he cut ties.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Carissa, I just mean when prosecutor & agents write, & judge reviews, T-III, everybody expects work will eventually be disclosed & litigated. Powerful incentive to exhibit consciousness of 4th Am & other protections.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Steve, there is a big difference between when an investigation is opened, which is an administrative act, and when something real is done on it. Fact they didn’t seek FISA until Oct doesn’t mean Page inv wasn’t open well before. Fact Pap inv open doesn’t mean they did much on it.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Randy, I think this will be bad. Because no counsel for target, FISA court expects DOJ to conform to high standard of disclosure re any credibility/ bias issues regarding sources in warrant app.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: My last thought of Twitter day: You should follow @CBHessick if you want to get smarter, but you better be ready to bring it. And you better be resigned that bringing it may not be good enough!
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I appreciate our exchange. It’ll make me more careful. I cop to hating spec-counsel investigations. I’m not Trump apologist, but I don’t like assignment of prosecutor w/o prob-cause of crime. If they’ve got provable crime, I’m all ears. But given gravity, should not be debatable.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: If you’re saying it’s theoretically possible to conspire in something that didn’t really happen, that’s clearly true - impossibility or failure is no defense. But hard to imagine charging collusion case on theory that the thing purportedly colluded in didn’t happen. /2
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Carissa, you’ve strained my brain to point I’m not sure I’m analyzing this as academic matter or as someone who’d have to convince a jury. If you’re going to charge someone w/ conspiracy to abet Russian hacking scheme, as practical matter, you must prove Russian hacking scheme./1
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I’m sorry if I wasn’t clear. M needs to prove Russia conspiracy to hack if allegation is that Trump peeps colluded in Russia hack. But if allegation is Trump peeps colluded w/ Russia on some other crime, it’s irrelevant whether Russia hacked ... right?
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Yup. I agree. But I’m not following how that bears on facts we’re dealing with. In abstract, I agree if you and I agreed to abet some hack, no need to prove Russia hacked. But why would we agree unless Russia actually hacked? In reality, isn’t the hack what prompts our agreement?
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: In abstract, I’m with you: If A & B agree to help C violate law, you have conspiracy to violate that law. But where does that get us? Are you saying Trump guys agreed to help Russia hack - ie they didn’t nec know Russia would hack but agreed to help them do so? Sorry to be dense.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Doesn’t mean Mueller doesn’t have evidence of more serious crimes. Means he doesn’t have FLYNN ACCOMPLICE evidence of such crimes. If M charges F w/such crimes post-plea, means F didn’t disclose them pre-plea, despite agreeing to full co-op w/ M. Wld destroy F’s value as witness.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Carissa, I’m relying on Mueller’s co-op agreement w/ Flynn. Gives him pass on other crimes related to plea crime. Plea already depicts Flynn as liar. If later indict him on new corruption crimes, means he must have withheld info, meaning he’s a worse liar & useless as witness. /1
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: If allegation is Trump & Russia in bribery conspiracy (eg, lift sanctions in exchange for $$$) - guilty if can prove it, & hacking irrelevant. But if allegation is Trump collusion in Russia hack conspiracy, gotta proveRussia hack conspiracy.
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Carissa, this is where I think you divert from what we’re talking about. If allegation is that you & friend conspired to sell drugs, you’re right - guilty. If allegation is you and friend conspired to participate in cartel’s drug dealing, gotta prove cartel’s drug dealing. /1
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: This doesn’t necessarily mean Mueller WANTS to impeach Trump. Means he is investigating to determine whether there’s a legitimate basis for doing so. /End
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: B/c no prosecutor would bank on being able to indict a POTUS, but there is precedent for impeaching POTUS based in part on obstruction, I continue to think impeachment is endgame. /19
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Exception is if goal is to nail main suspect on a process crime, like obstruction. Perverting process is theme of obstruction case, not so problematic to have convicted liar witnesses. /18
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: It would have made them better cooperating witnesses. You don’t build good witness by pleading him to lying to the FBI - why wouldn’t he then lie to jury too? /17
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I know SDNY practices are not nationwide, but they are prudent. Mueller’s a smart guy. If they’d have given him that evidence, he’d have made them plead to it & gotten it into public domain. /16
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: My point is that if they’d given Mueller cyber-esp conspiracy proof, he’d have had them plead to that. /15
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Puzzled by Prof Hessick’s assertion that I don’t think Flynn & Papadoupoulos cooperating. I’ve said they are — fact statements accompanying pleas make that obvious. /14
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: That, tho, would be diversion from collusion hypothesis that launched investigation. It would not depend on a Russian hack attack - separate conspiracy (tho could say related one). /13
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Of course it’s theoretically possible that there was some other Russia-Trump conspiracy. Indeed, I believe Mueller (& FBI/DOJ before him) theorize possible quid-pro-quo on sanctions relief. /12
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: N.B.: I am not saying cyber-esp is only conceivable conspiracy. Just that cyber-esp is linchpin of collusion narrative (i.e., Russia hacked election & Trump somehow coordinated in that). /11
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: If I am right, Mueller’s prob is not just that he can’t prove Russia did the hacking; can’t prove it orchestrated conspiracy to do so. That conspiracy has to provably exist for Trump peeps to join it. /10
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Completely agree w/ Prof. Hessick that we do not know all the facts. B/c so much public dispute, I believe we’d have heard if there were solid proof. But I could absolutely be wrong about that. /9
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I see this as a PROOF problem, not a legal theory problem. I stipulate there was, in fact, a cyber-esp conspiracy. Q is whether Mueller has sufficient courtroom proof of it. /8
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: That’s why, in collusion context we’ve been discussing for a year, cyber-esp is critical. It is conspiracy crime Russia & its agents carried out, & Trump campaign suspected of colluding in. /7
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Flaw in @CBHessick argument is subtle shift from cyber-esp to “help Russia”. It’s not a crime to help Russia, or agree to do so. Have to help them, or agree to help them, DO SOMETHING CRIMINAL. /6
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: Still, agreement on specific criminal objective must be proved beyond reas’l doubt. Unless prosecutor can prove A & B agreed, there’s no agreement for C to join. /5
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I’m well aware that conspiracy is mere agreement, need not succeed, and once shown very little evidence needed to connect someone to it. /4
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I expressly take it as a given that Russia conducted a cyberespionage (cyber-esp) attack. Trump questions this (on occasion) but I don’t, so I don’t see how I’m contributing to hoax narrative. /3
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: I don't question legal principles she lays out, but I am talking about facts as we know them. /2
author: AndrewCMcCarthy

text: B/c I have great respect for the excellent @CBHessick, taking time to respond to criticism I think misplaced. Either I wasn't clear enough or she’s misunderstood me on the following. /1
author: AndrewCMcCarthy
